_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT FARM SERVICE COMPANY, HENDERSON, IOWA

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1995 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Henderson Volunteer Fire Department (via 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency.  Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Mills County, Iowa LEPC will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected, and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned.  In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned.  In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Henderson, Iowa location is James Russmann, Agronomy Manager.  His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document.  In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:

              James Russmann, Agronomy Manager
                    WORK:       (712) 323-7167
                    24-hour:     (712) 323-6405
                    Mobile:        (402) 681-5581

              Mark Knop, Assistant
                    WORK:        (712) 825-3561
                    24-hour:      (712) 825-3581

Mobile:         (712) 370-5561

               Denny Viner, Assistant
                     WORK:        (712) 825-3561
                     24-hour:      (712) 825-5752
                     Mobile:         (712) 370-6561

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT, AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT FARM SERVICE COMPANY, HENDERSON, IOWA:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant.  The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The system consists of two (2) 12,000-gallon storage tanks, one Anhydrous Ammonia, with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment.  The plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall).  Fulltime equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis.  At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year).  The FTE's for this company location is two (2).

THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:

The worst-case scenario is the failure of the one (1) 12,000-gallon Anhydrous Ammonia storage tank, when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud-Anhydrous Ammonia) form.  The distance to the endpoint is .79 miles.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity to the town of Henderson, provisions have been designed to notify all affected persons.  An evacuation plan is in place.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. 

In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Finally, Fa

rm Service Company has extended to the Henderson Volunteer Fire Department the opportunity to visit our plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Farm Service Company, Henderson, Iowa has never had an accident involving Anhydrous Ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our system, it is the policy of Farm Service Company to immediately notify the Henderson Volunteer Fire Department and the Mills County, Iowa LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the Henderson Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our Henderson location, the Volumteer Fire Department with whom Henderson has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.  We have discussed this policy with the Fire Department and with Mills County LEPC.  Members of the Fire Department and the LEPC have inspected our Anhydrous Ammonia plant.
